At 22:41 19/08/2004, you wrote:
>On Thu, 19 Aug 2004 13:51:50 -0700, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> 
>wrote:
> > What do you guys think?  What have you done to deal with this problem?  Did
> > you just tweak stuff until you got good results?  Or have you analyzed the
> > problem and determined an optimal solution?
>
>Well, if the problem really is as you've conceptualized it, that you
>want to mutate a topology, then only perturb weights before adding new
>topology, you could implement something similar to Colin's phased
>approach.  Only instead of alternating phases of adding and
>subtracting topology, you could have alternating phases of adding
>topology and mutating weights only.
>
>Otherwise, yeah, it sounds like it's just a matter of experimenting
>and tweaking to find the appropriate mutation rate.

How about always adding new topology with its weight(s) set to zero (and 
not turning off the connection it replaces).

That way the addition of new topology is always a minor disruption and the 
topology then hangs around and can have weight-increasing mutations tried 
on many occasions to give it the chance to become relevent.

Oh, and from the point of view of culling, any connection which has not 
managed to get its weight increased to more than 1% of the other weights on 
its node after (say) 500 generations is a candidate for culling.

As is any node whose total contribution to down-stream nodes remains 
similarly minute.
